article.title: Validation of a New Rodent Experimental System to Investigate Consequences of Long Duration Space Habitation
article.abstract: Animal models are useful for exploring the health consequences of prolonged spaceflight. Capabilities were developed to perform experiments in low earth orbit with on-board sample recovery, thereby avoiding complications caused by return to Earth.

sections.introduction: Space travel over the past five decades reveals that multiple organ systems are influenced by novel environmental conditions above the Earth’s surface.
sections.methods: The Rodent Research Transporter and Habitats performed as expected for the duration of the flight.
sections.results: Mice flown on the RR-1 mission were designated as either NASA “Validation” mice (Female C57BL/6J, 16 wks) or ISS National Lab “Experimental” mice (Female C57BL/6NTac, 32 wks) to achieve the main objectives.
sections.discussion: The main objective of this work was to develop new capability for conducting long duration, rodent experiments in space which both minimize the complications of non-specific, chronic stress responses and allow for sample recovery on-orbit,

article.insights_summary: This study validates a new rodent experimental system for investigating the consequences of long duration space habitation. The system allows for sample recovery on-orbit, minimizing the complications of non-specific, chronic stress responses.
article.acknowledgments: We particularly thank David Pletcher, Cecilia Wigley, San Huei Lai-Polo, Rebeccca A. Klotz, and the entire NASA Ames Research Center team who worked on the RR-1 mission.
